answers.answer: The fact that she isn't thirsty tends to indicate that her glucose levels are not high, for thirst is the primary symptom to look for. I would recommend that you just continue her healthy meals and have chopped veggies handy for those snacks if she is hungry. If her weight is above normal, then you may have to adjust her portions or feed her small amounts throughout the day in order to keep her from getting hungry and overeating at a big meal.

question: Hi!  I am the mother of a 7 year old little girl.  Over the past several months she has started gaining weight, especially around her abdomen.  I am a nurse and of course my mind goes crazy.  She was premature at birth, 4# 1.6oz, 34 weeks gestation.  She has never had any health problems other than being early and little.  Since she started school last year she has grown alot in height, but with that her weight is climbing more and more.  If we eat dinner at 6:30pm, by 7:30pm she is already starting with "I am starving, can I have something to eat".  She is very active with PE 3 times a week and she also takes 2 hours of dance per week, and on the weekends is outside playing with friends.  I have noticed that when she was younger she would drink alot more than she does now.  Sometimes she can eat a whole meal and only take several sips of Milk (skim).  If I tell her to drink her Milk she always says I am not thirsty, which is also a concern.  I know diabetes runs in my family, not so much in my husbands family.  Should I be concerned or is this just a phase that I need to watch.  We tend to eat a heart healty diet with fish, fruit, salads, and I use alot of olive oil and whole wheat bread.  Thanks for your advise.Sweetpeasmom
title: 7 year old eating all the time
